ticket.title: index "unique_schema_migrations" should use table prefix/suffix
ticket.original-body:
Create 2 rails apps, both of which share a database schema and use different table name prefixes.
in app1/config/environment.rb: config.active_record_table_name_prefix = 'app1_'
in app2/config/environment.rb: config.active_record_table_name_prefix = 'app2_'
The apps will correctly use the names app1_schema_migrations and app2_schema_migrations to hold migrations. However, both will try to create an index named "unique_schema_migrations" on their table. The second app which does this will get an error.
Attached patch adds any table prefix / suffix to the name of the unique_schema_migrations index.
ticket.latest-body:
Create 2 rails apps, both of which share a database schema and use different table name prefixes.
in app1/config/environment.rb: config.active_record_table_name_prefix = 'app1_'
in app2/config/environment.rb: config.active_record_table_name_prefix = 'app2_'
The apps will correctly use the names app1_schema_migrations and app2_schema_migrations to hold migrations. However, both will try to create an index named "unique_schema_migrations" on their table. The second app which does this will get an error.
Attached patch adds any table prefix / suffix to the name of the unique_schema_migrations index.
ticket.original-body-html:
Create 2 rails apps, both of which share a database schema and use different table name prefixes.

in app1/config/environment.rb: config.active_record_table_name_prefix = 'app1_'

in app2/config/environment.rb: config.active_record_table_name_prefix = 'app2_'

The apps will correctly use the names app1_schema_migrations and app2_schema_migrations to hold migrations. However, both will try to create an index named "unique_schema_migrations" on their table. The second app which does this will get an error.

Attached patch adds any table prefix / suffix to the name of the unique_schema_migrations index.

version.body:
Create 2 rails apps, both of which share a database schema and use different table name prefixes.
in app1/config/environment.rb: config.active_record_table_name_prefix = 'app1_'
in app2/config/environment.rb: config.active_record_table_name_prefix = 'app2_'
The apps will correctly use the names app1_schema_migrations and app2_schema_migrations to hold migrations. However, both will try to create an index named "unique_schema_migrations" on their table. The second app which does this will get an error.
Attached patch adds any table prefix / suffix to the name of the unique_schema_migrations index.
version.body-html:
Create 2 rails apps, both of which share a database schema and use different table name prefixes.

in app1/config/environment.rb: config.active_record_table_name_prefix = 'app1_'

in app2/config/environment.rb: config.active_record_table_name_prefix = 'app2_'

The apps will correctly use the names app1_schema_migrations and app2_schema_migrations to hold migrations. However, both will try to create an index named "unique_schema_migrations" on their table. The second app which does this will get an error.

Attached patch adds any table prefix / suffix to the name of the unique_schema_migrations index.
version.title: index "unique_schema_migrations" should use table prefix/suffix

version.body:
+1
When I created the index I decided to use the `add_index` method instead of custom SQL, because I assumed it added the correct prefixes. I now see that it doesn't (not when using `:name` anyway), just as `create_table` doesn't either.
version.body-html:
+1

When I created the index I decided to use the add_index method instead of custom SQL, because I assumed it added the correct prefixes. I now see that it doesn't (not when using :name anyway), just as create_table doesn't either.
version.title: index "unique_schema_migrations" should use table prefix/suffix

version.body: Looks reasonable to me, could we have a test for this too?
version.body-html: Looks reasonable to me, could we have a test for this too?
version.title: index "unique_schema_migrations" should use table prefix/suffix

version.body: Added a patch with test.
version.body-html: Added a patch with test.
version.title: index "unique_schema_migrations" should use table prefix/suffix

version.body:
+1
Patch applies cleanly to edge and the tests are passing.
version.body-html:
+1

Patch applies cleanly to edge and the tests are passing.
version.title: index "unique_schema_migrations" should use table prefix/suffix

version.body:
+1 Patch applies cleanly on 2-3-stable as tests pass too.
Is it really necessary for 2 applications to create the same index ? i think it's something the developer and the DBA should decide before, no reason to create 2 unique indexes, can someone please come up with a case example ?
version.body-html:
+1 Patch applies cleanly on 2-3-stable as tests pass too.

Is it really necessary for 2 applications to create the same index ? i think it's something the developer and the DBA should decide before, no reason to create 2 unique indexes, can someone please come up with a case example ?
version.title: index "unique_schema_migrations" should use table prefix/suffix

version.body: @elad: since two schema_migrations tables are created, each needs a different index
version.body-html: @elad: since two schema_migrations tables are created, each needs a different index
version.title: index "unique_schema_migrations" should use table prefix/suffix

version.body: verified
version.body-html: verified
version.title: index "unique_schema_migrations" should use table prefix/suffix

version.body:
Thanks for attending to this old issue :)
Minor comment: Christi's patch fixes the actual bug, but names the index starting with "unique" instead of the application prefix. The point of using a prefix is that all the objects in a shared schema can be grouped by name; the original patch named the index correctly.
version.body-html:
Thanks for attending to this old issue :)

Minor comment: Christi's patch fixes the actual bug, but names the index starting with "unique" instead of the application prefix. The point of using a prefix is that all the objects in a shared schema can be grouped by name; the original patch named the index correctly.
version.title: index "unique_schema_migrations" should use table prefix/suffix

version.body:
verified
The patch apply cleanly. All tests pass.
+1 I think Tim is right.
version.body-html:
verified

The patch apply cleanly. All tests pass.

+1 I think Tim is right.
version.title: index "unique_schema_migrations" should use table prefix/suffix

version.body: This supra footwear is called a modern vintage and has been since their introduction in 2003 where they began in Europe. Every supra shoes has some type of ornament, adornment or hardware and is comprised of aged leather that is bought from around the world. These supra uk are culturally engaging and allow for the woman wearing them to be enveloped in luxury.With new cuts and styles and hand stitched shoes, these timberland boots, heels or flats will make every foot look like it stepped out of vintage Hollywood. This timberland shoes have been worn and coveted by many of the most famous females in recent history. One such coach outlet, Jennifer Aniston, wears them in public and at home.This company makes many different unique styles of bags outlet from ankle booties to sandals, pumps, moncler jackets online, platforms and wedges. One louis vuitton bag in particular is ideal for the gothic style sense; it is patent leather and laces up the front of the shaft. There are also zippers on each side, and this shoe offers a flat heel of a half inch.Another great moncler jackets sale is featured in People's Style Watch and is called a platform bootie. This ture religion jeans has a raised panel in front of the ankle as well as a heel that measures 4.5 inches. The front offers a leather bandage appearance and is considered high fashion.
